column4: i'm considering switching to ubuntu, but i have a program that i use for our homeschool recordkeeping and they do not currently support linus os - wine & codeweaver do not support the program either - what are my options?
sorry - hi, my name is mandi LOL
have you tried running the app in codeweavers crossover office?
I've seen a great number of apps not listed run fine.
since ubuntu runs as a live cd, you could test it, including installing crossover office, without overwriting windows.
i haven't switched yet, from what i understand, part of the problem is that the program heavily relies on .NET framework - does this matter?
it does.  that doesn't mean it automatically won't run in crossover though.
any chance you can plug in an ethernet cable for testing? :)
not on this computer, but my "server" is connected directly to the modem, so i could use that for testing
that one is going to be my 100% linux machine, my others might have to be dual-booted
wouldn't hurt to do testing on something you could afford to run linux on :)
I dual booted for a couple of years before finally ditching windows all together. :)
i've talked to several converts, also homeschoolers, and the only reason they still use windows is because of this program i speak of

when i do a ful install on linux on my old desktop machine (the 100% linux machine), do i need to move the data to CDs, or just back them up in case something happens? how much of the data gets wiped in an os install?
all of it.  I'd back up to storage you trust.  whether it's a USB drive, or whatever.
if the machine isn't important.  install linux and run with it :)  test everything you think you might do with a main computer.  of course be sure to back up your data first.
skinnypup, thanks for the input - i'll let you know how it turns out!
